title: The Year of Release
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 15 outlines God's instructions for the year of release every seven years, emphasizing debt forgiveness, care for the poor, and the release of Hebrew servants. This chapter highlights God's provision, justice, and mercy, teaching Israel to trust Him and live generously in obedience to His commands.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Wanderings, just before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: The Hebrew Servant
keyCharacters.description: A fellow Israelite who serves another for six years and is to be released in the seventh year with provisions.

keyCharacters.name: The Creditor
keyCharacters.description: An Israelite who lends to his neighbor and is commanded to forgive debts every seven years as an act of obedience to God.

keyCharacters.name: The Poor Brother
keyCharacters.description: A member of Israel in need, who is to be treated with generosity and compassion, reflecting God's heart for the needy.

definitions.definition: The cancellation of debts and release of Hebrew servants every seventh year, symbolizing God's provision and mercy.
A wooden peg or earring pierced through the ear of a servant who chooses to remain with his master permanently.
The firstborn male animal from a herd or flock, set apart as holy and dedicated to the Lord.
One who lends money or goods to another, expected to forgive debts to fellow Israelites in the year of release.

outline.heading: The Year of Release and Debt Forgiveness
outline.description: God commands the Israelites to cancel debts every seven years, emphasizing mercy and trust in His provision. This release applies to fellow Israelites but not to foreigners, highlighting the covenant community's special relationship.

outline.heading: Generosity Toward the Poor
outline.description: Believers are urged to open their hands generously to the poor among them, warning against withholding help out of selfishness or fear of the upcoming release year.

outline.heading: Release of Hebrew Servants
outline.description: Instructions are given for the release of Hebrew servants after six years of service, including providing for them generously upon their departure, remembering Israel’s own redemption from Egypt.

outline.heading: Sanctification of Firstborn Animals
outline.description: The firstborn males of livestock are to be dedicated to the Lord, eaten in His presence, and not sacrificed if blemished, underscoring holiness and obedience in worship practices.

application: Trust God’s provision by practicing generosity and forgiving debts or offenses as He commands.
Cultivate a compassionate heart toward those in need, remembering God’s blessings and commands to help the poor.
Honor God’s redemption by treating others with kindness and fairness, especially those who serve us.
Dedicate the firstfruits of your blessings to the Lord as an act of worship and acknowledgment of His sovereignty.

keyVerses.text: At the end of every seven years thou shalt make a release.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the foundational principle of debt forgiveness and rest, reflecting God's mercy and provision.

keyVerses.text: If there be among you a poor man of one of thy brethren within any of thy gates in thy land which the LORD thy God giveth thee, thou shalt not harden thine heart, nor shut thine hand from thy poor brother:
keyVerses.significance: It commands believers to respond with compassion and generosity toward those in need, reflecting God’s heart.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt remember that thou wast a bondman in the land of Egypt, and the LORD thy God redeemed thee: therefore I command thee this thing to day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse grounds the command to release servants in Israel’s own experience of redemption, encouraging empathy and obedience.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt surely give him, and thine heart shall not be grieved when thou givest unto him: because that for this thing the LORD thy God shall bless thee in all thy works, and in all that thou puttest thine hand unto.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches that giving generously is a blessing and should be done cheerfully, trusting God’s promise of provision.
